title: Russia-Ukraine: Trump calls Putin 'crazy‚Äô after largest air attacks of war
description:
In Ukraine, swarms of Russian drones filled the skies for a third night in a row as Moscow stepped up its largest aerial assault of the war.

(Subscribe: https://bit.ly/C4_News_Subscribe) 

Ukrainian officials say at least 30 people have been killed and more than 160 injured over the weekend, amid American attempts to broker a ceasefire.

The attacks drew the ire of Donald Trump, who claimed Vladimir Putin had gone 'absolutely crazy'.

The Kremlin, meanwhile, downplayed what they called 'emotional reactions'.

title: ‚ÄúPin-Headed THUG‚Äù | Trump BLASTS Putin After Russia Attack Ukraine
description:
Donald Trump called Vladimir Putin ‚Äúabsolutely crazy‚Äù after Russia launched its biggest aerial attack of the war on Ukraine, killing at least 13 people.

Trump, posting on Truth Social, said he used to have a good relationship with Putin but now believes "something has happened to him." He warned that Putin wants "all of Ukraine" and that such actions could lead to Russia‚Äôs downfall.

The attack, which included 298 drones and 69 missiles, was the largest so far in terms of weapons fired. Ukraine shot down most of them, but dozens were killed or wounded, including children.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy urged stronger global action, saying silence only emboldens Putin and that more sanctions are needed.

Alex Phillips speaks with former US Army (Europe) commander, Lieutenant General Ben Hodges.

title: Russian Bombing Leaves Kyiv Devastated | Trump Condemns Putin | Russia Ukraine War
description:
In yet another devastating blow to Ukraine, Russia launched its largest air attack yet, targeting Kyiv for the second consecutive night with drones and missiles. The massive assault left several districts in ruins, forcing residents to take shelter in subway stations. Debris from intercepted and missed missiles caused widespread destruction ‚Äî with smoke rising across six areas of the city. Tragically, innocent lives were lost, and children are among the injured.
This escalation comes just after a prisoner exchange deal that was seen as a hopeful step toward ceasefire. However, the renewed aggression casts doubt on the peace process.
The attack also drew international reactions. Former U.S. President Donald Trump, who has been engaged in back-channel negotiations to help end the war, publicly condemned Putin for the assault on Kyiv

description:

title: Trump rebukes Putin as Russia hits Ukraine with record drone attack | BBC News
description:
US President Donald Trump has rebuked Russian President Vladimir Putin after another weekend of Russian missile and drone attacks on Ukraine.
 
On Saturday night into Sunday, Russia fired 367 drones and missiles at Ukraine, killing at least 12 people. The attacks continued on Sunday night into Monday, including in Kyiv.
 
Trump also criticised Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky.
 
Russia said it intercepted 96 Ukrainian drones across 12 regions overnight, including six over Moscow.

title: Russia mounts biggest air attack on Ukraine ahead of prisoner swap
description:
Russia mounts biggest air attack on Ukraine ahead of prisoner swap

#breakingnews #news #russia #ukraine 

Russian forces launched its largest aerial attack of the war so far across Ukraine, killing at least 12 people overnight, Ukrainian officials said on Sunday (May 25), just hours before Russia and Ukraine completed the exchange of 1,000 prisoners each, in the largest such swap since the war began three years ago. Diane To reports.

Explosions were heard in Ukraine's capital Kyiv overnight, as Russia launched the war's largest aerial attack across the country...

hours before the two sides completed their third and final round of a major prisoner swap.

Residents took shelter in an underground metro station in Kyiv during the assault - the second in two days.

State Emergency Service of Kyiv Region

State emergency services released footage said to show the aftermath of the attacks in other areas, with homes seen on fire in Kyiv region's Markhalivka.

Reuters was able to verify the locations and date of the videos.

According to Ukraine's air force, Russia had launched nearly 370 drones and missiles in its overnight assault.

It said it was able to shoot down most of them.

Children were among those killed, officials said.

::State Emergency Service of Ukraine

Mykolaiv in the south was among other regional centres also hit - as well as Ternopil in the west and Ukraine's second-largest city, Kharkiv.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky called for action from the United States, which has taken a softer line on Russia and its leader, Vladimir Putin, since President Donald Trump took office.

"The silence of America, the silence of others in the world only encourages Putin," Zelensky wrote on Telegram.

"Every such terrorist Russian strike is reason enough for new sanctions against Russia," he added.

:: Coordination Headquarters for the Treatment of Prisoners of War

Later on Sunday, Russia and Ukraine confirmed they had swapped 303 prisoners each, completing the three-day exchange of a total of 1,000 prisoners each.

:: Ombudsman Dmytro Lubinets

Ukrainian authorities released video showing its citizens freed from Russian captivity eating chocolate for the first time in three years.

Reuters was unable to independently verify the location of the footage, but the environment matches earlier video put out showing the previous days' prisoner swaps.

::Russian Defence Ministry

Russia's Defence Ministry also published video showing soldiers on a bus celebrating their release.

The exchange was the biggest since the war began three years ago.

It was the only concrete step towards peace to emerge from the first direct talks between the two sides on May 16, when they failed to agree on a ceasefire.

title: Putin's team split in two over Ukrainian war and money, putting the dictator in a difficult position
description:
#Kanal13‚Äã #likekanal13‚Äã #subscribekanal13 #warinukraine
https://www.youtube.com/user/kanal13az?sub_confirmation=1 - SUBSCRIBE TO US!
Russian dictator Vladimir Putin has three to four months to use his last chance to occupy Ukrainian territories as much as possible. In the meantime, two groups of influence have formed in his entourage, which are trying to advance their interests related to the war in Ukraine.

Military analyst and director of the New Geopolitics Research Network platform Mikhail Samus spoke about this in an interview with Telegraf . He explained what options for the development of events are being offered to Putin.

 ‚ÄúThere is a group of FSB businesses headed by Kirill Dmitriev, head of the Russian Direct Investment Fund, which, through Vitkoff and Jared Kushner, is proposing to the US the idea of a ceasefire, freezing the war and starting a big business between the US and Russia. They are promising big profits to American businesses close to Trump‚Äù, says the military expert.

In his opinion, this will be billions of dollars from the sale of Russian gas to Europe under the American label, diamond mining in Yakutia, Arctic projects, etc. ‚ÄúAll this is huge money for specific people. And there are people in Russia who would like to go down this path. This is, first of all, big business, Putin's oligarchy, which lost a lot from the war, and they would like to return to this money that can be earned on Russian resources‚Äù, explains the director of the New Geopolitics Research Network.

According to him, there is another group that now has a dominant position. This is the "old guard": Patrushev, Kiriyenko, Vaino, Chemezov, who are doing business on the war.

"They have trillion-dollar budgets for war, and they are spending them. Why does Sergey Chemezov, CEO of the Rostec corporation‚Äù need a ceasefire now if his military contracts are already written down for a year in advance? If there is a freeze on the war, the military budget will be reduced," the analyst notes.

He recalled experts' predictions that when the war in Ukraine freezes, the Russians will continue to build up their potential and then prepare for war with Europe.

title: Russia fires hundreds of drones and missiles at Ukraine in one of the largest attacks of the war
description:
Russia launched hundreds of long-range drones and 69 missiles at Ukraine in one of the largest aerial attacks since the war began in 2022.

Authorities say at least 12 people were killed in the strikes, including three children in the Zhytomyr region, west of Kyiv.

Ukraine's air force said it downed 266 drones and 45 missiles.

title: Russia's Largest Missile & Drone Attack on Ukraine | Subscribe to Firstpost | N18G
description:
Russia's Largest Missile & Drone Attack on Ukraine | Subscribe to Firstpost | N18G

Russia launched its "largest" air attack on Ukraine in three years of the war. The Ukrainian military said Russia launched 367 missiles and drones overnight. The Ukrainian military said downed 45 Russian missiles & 266 attack drones. The Russian strikes hit the Ukrainian capital Kyiv and other regions, killing at least 12 people and injuring 16. Ukrainian President Zelensky called on the US and EU to pressure Russia to stop the war. Renewed attacks follow strikes on the intervening night of May 23 and 24. Russia also claimed Ukrainian drone attacks on both days. Attacks come amid the biggest prisoner swap between Russia and Ukraine, with each side releasing 1,000 prisoners of war each in a three-day swap. The swap comes amid Donald Trump's push for a ceasefire. Russian and Ukrainian officials held their first face-to-face talks in Istanbul last week.

title: The War is Now in Russia: Putin Humiliated as Ukrainian strikes SHUT DOWN airports in Capital Moscow
description:
Is Russia‚Äôs war on Ukraine driving the Kremlin toward economic, military, and social collapse? In this in-depth report, we uncover the May 21 drone attacks that rattled Moscow‚Äôs defenses‚Äîand how a larger, more strategic strike 400 kilometers away devastated a critical semiconductor factory vital to Russia‚Äôs missile and aircraft programs. Beyond the drone raids, we expose the staggering human costs and equipment losses Russia has suffered, the unsustainable militarization of its economy, and the growing gulf between propaganda and reality in Putin‚Äôs regime.

From drastic government spending on defense to the hidden toll on its workforce and infrastructure, this video reveals why experts predict that Russia‚Äôs current path is economically and socially untenable‚Äîand why Vladimir Putin appears more isolated and vulnerable than ever. Join us for a comprehensive look at a conflict reshaping global power dynamics and threatening to dismantle the Kremlin‚Äôs imperial ambitions from within.

title: Russia-Ukraine analyst: Russia 'has started to lose' the war in Ukraine | DW News
description:
On Wednesday, the Kremin announced that Russian President Vladimir Putin had visited Russia's Kursk region on Tuesday. It marked Putin's first visit since Moscow claimed it recaptured Kursk from Ukraininan forces last month. Ukraine's incursion into Kursk in 2024 was the first time a foreign power occupied Russian territory since World War II. 
President Putin has not yet accepted US and European ceasefire proposals, stating that the "root causes of the war" need to be addressed before negotiations can begin. On Wednesday, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov said the motive for a Western-backed truce is for the US and Europe to "calmly arm Ukraine, so that Ukraine can strengthen its defensive positions". 

DW interviews Michael Kimmage, Historian and Associate Professor at the Catholic University of America. He served on the Policy Planning Staff at the U.S. Department of State between 2014 to 2016, where he held the Russia/Ukraine portfolio.

title: Russia-Ukraine War: Putin Visits Kursk For The First Time After Ukrainian Troop Withdrawal |GRAVITAS
description:
Russian President Vladimir Putin visited the Kursk region for the first time since Russian forces pushed out Ukrainian troops last month. He acknowledged the continued challenges in the border area and announced extended financial support for affected residents. Meanwhile, drone footage released by Russia shows a missile strike on a Ukrainian training camp in Sumy, reportedly killing six, though Moscow claims much higher casualties. Amid the escalation, Ukrainian President Zelensky has signaled readiness to meet Putin directly, following calls with U.S. President Trump, though no major progress has been made toward a ceasefire.

title: Russia reactivates Cold War bases - right on Nato's border
description:
Almost a million Russian personnel are estimated to have been killed, captured or wounded fighting in Ukraine and Kursk.

But despite those staggering losses, Russian president Vladimir Putin is still likely to have a bigger military when this conflict ends than when it began.

And there are indications that Moscow is already preparing its post-war posture, with signs that Russia is beefing up its military presence along its western border.

title: Ukraine has started evacuating people from Sumy region | DW News
description:
Ukrainian authorities have begun evacuating people from dozens of locations in the Sumy region near the border with Russia. So far, officials have brought over 50,000 people to safety, according to the region's military governor. He says that's about half the number of civilians who need to evacuate. Russia has been heavily attacking Sumy for months. On the other side of the border, Russian President Vladimir Putin has visited Kursk for the first time since Russia said it expelled Ukrainian forces in April. He visited a nuclear plant, which is under construction.

title: Ukraine launches massive attack on Moscow and central regions of Russia with over 150 drones
description:
#Kanal13‚Äã #likekanal13‚Äã #subscribekanal13 #warinukraine
https://www.youtube.com/user/kanal13az?sub_confirmation=1 - SUBSCRIBE TO US!
Attacks on Russia from the Armed Forces continue. Only for today's night in the sky above the Russian Air Force destroyed more than a hundred unmanned aerial vehicles. Details about this have been reported to the Ministry of Defense.

¬´Over the night 127 Ukrainian unmanned aerial vehicles of the aircraft type were intercepted and destroyed by air defense units on duty", ‚Äî says the message of the Telegram channel of the Ministry of Defense.

Ukraine directed its main attack at the Oryol region. According to the Russian Defense Ministry, 53 unmanned aircraft-type aerial vehicles were destroyed in the skies over the Oryol region.

The attack continued all night, and the last 16 drones were shot down in the morning, around eight o'clock Moscow time. There were no reports of casualties or deaths at the time of publication. The region's governor, Andrei Klychkov, said on his Telegram channel that the aftermath of the attack on the ground was being clarified. Drones attacked the Bolkhov factory of semiconductor devices in the Oryol region of the Russian Federation. Photos from the scene of the accident are spreading on social networks: they show a fire and a column of black smoke.

According to the Russian Telegram-channels, the company is connected with the military industry and produces components for radio-electronic equipment, including communication systems, control systems, EW, as well as simulators for tanks and missile complexes.

The plant's products are used by the defense concern "Sozvezdie" and other structures of the Armed Forces of Ukraine.

Six UAVs were intercepted and destroyed by electronic warfare and air defense systems in the Moscow region, three over the territory of the Ryazan region, one each in the skies of the Tula and Kaluga regions, and also over the waters of the Black Sea.

The border regions of Russia were also attacked. The most massive strike of the Ukrainian Armed Forces was in the Bryansk region. The Russian Ministry of Defense reported 51 drones destroyed over the Bryansk region. 36 UAVs were shot down over the Kursk region, and one over the Belgorod region.

The total number of Ukrainian drones destroyed over Russian regions on May 21 increased by 08:00 Moscow time from 127 to 159 units. No drones were spotted in the Samara Region at the time of publication. The threat of attack regime declared at night remains in effect.

title: Russia launching WWII-style breakthrough in Sumy; Ukrainian snipers mass-kill Russian soldiers here
description:
#Kanal13‚Äã #likekanal13‚Äã #subscribekanal13 #warinukraine
https://www.youtube.com/user/kanal13az?sub_confirmation=1 - SUBSCRIBE TO US!
Viktor Bobyrenko, an analyst at the Bureau of Policy and Analysis of Ukraine, believes that the landscape of the Sumy region and the nature of modern warfare will prevent Russian forces from breaking through Ukrainian defenses.
"To avoid sparking panic, let me say right away ‚Äî a large-scale breakthrough in the style of World War II is not possible in Sumy. People here remember 2022, when Russia advanced and was, so to speak, on the outskirts of Sumy by midday. By February 25, the city was sealed off and under siege for a month. Today, there will be no such breakthrough where the enemy reaches Sumy in a day. Warfare is different now.
It‚Äôs simply not feasible because the terrain between the Siverskyi Donets and Psel rivers is not suited for tanks ‚Äî it‚Äôs full of floodplains and a network of ponds. You can‚Äôt maneuver tanks there. However, it‚Äôs a paradise for sabotage and reconnaissance groups and snipers: a landscape with forests and woodlands, the edge of the Central Russian highlands," the analyst explained on Espreso TV.
According to him, Russian forces might try to use this area as a "gray zone," given reports that Russia has amassed over 60,000 troops nearby. So there could be engagements similar to those near Pokrovsk ‚Äî advances of maybe 500 meters a day at most. At that pace, it would take them six months to a year to reach Sumy. Therefore, there's no reason to panic about a rapid breakthrough in the region.
"Still, Russian artillery can strike up to 20 kilometers deep, as seen in Bilopillia, and FPV drones are active. For instance, on May 17, a minivan was hit by Russian forces just 11 km from the front line on the Sumy‚ÄìBilopillia‚ÄìPutyvl‚ÄìHlukhiv‚ÄìShostka highway. The railway is nearby too. When a train runs from Sumy to Konotop, it speeds up to pass through this high-risk zone near the border. It‚Äôs possible the Russians aim to cut this road, which connects Sumy with communities north of the Siverskyi Donets River. In that sense, they could advance here.
But back in 1943, the Red Army advanced elsewhere ‚Äî around the Pysarivka community, aiming to reach the rear of Kharkiv and sever the Sumy‚ÄìKharkiv highway and rail links. That area lies further south than where the current intense fighting is happening," Bobyrenko concluded.

title: Russian Defeat LOOMS in Ukraine... Putin CAN‚ÄôT ESCAPE This TIME!
description:
On May 19, Foreign Policy detailed why experts now believe Russia is on the brink of defeat in Ukraine. Since the February 2022 invasion, Russia has lost nearly 976,000 troops to death, injury, or capture and over 10,800 tanks. Territorial gains have declined steadily, with only 55‚Äì78 square miles claimed in March 2025.

Compounding these losses is a stagnating Russian economy, with inflation nearing 10% and labor shortages projected to reach 2.4 million workers by 2030. Politically, Putin faces growing pressure as ceasefire negotiations stall and public dissatisfaction rises. As Ukraine begins counter-offensives, experts suggest Russia‚Äôs campaign is not just faltering ‚Äî it may be nearing collapse.

title: Trump Says Russia, Ukraine to Start Truce Talks Immediately
description:
President Donald Trump said that Moscow and Kyiv would begin talks ‚Äúimmediately‚Äù on ending the war in Ukraine after a phone call with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Monday.

‚ÄúRussia and Ukraine will immediately start negotiations toward a Ceasefire and, more importantly, an END to the War,‚Äù Trump said in a social-media post. ‚ÄúThe conditions for that will be negotiated between the two parties, as it can only be, because they know details of a negotiation that nobody else would be aware of.‚Äù

description:
The EU and Britain have announced new sanctions on Russia after yesterday's much-hyped phone call between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin failed to break ground on any potential peace deal.

This week saw a spate of elections where the continent faced stark choices between pro-Russia populists and liberal leaders committed to the defence of Ukraine. Their results may re-shape Europe itself.

title: Russia launching WWII-style breakthrough in Sumy; Ukrainian snipers mass-kill Russian soldiers here
description:
#Kanal13‚Äã #likekanal13‚Äã #subscribekanal13 #warinukraine
https://www.youtube.com/user/kanal13az?sub_confirmation=1 - SUBSCRIBE TO US!
Viktor Bobyrenko, an analyst at the Bureau of Policy and Analysis of Ukraine, believes that the landscape of the Sumy region and the nature of modern warfare will prevent Russian forces from breaking through Ukrainian defenses.
"To avoid sparking panic, let me say right away ‚Äî a large-scale breakthrough in the style of World War II is not possible in Sumy. People here remember 2022, when Russia advanced and was, so to speak, on the outskirts of Sumy by midday. By February 25, the city was sealed off and under siege for a month. Today, there will be no such breakthrough where the enemy reaches Sumy in a day. Warfare is different now.
It‚Äôs simply not feasible because the terrain between the Siverskyi Donets and Psel rivers is not suited for tanks ‚Äî it‚Äôs full of floodplains and a network of ponds. You can‚Äôt maneuver tanks there. However, it‚Äôs a paradise for sabotage and reconnaissance groups and snipers: a landscape with forests and woodlands, the edge of the Central Russian highlands," the analyst explained on Espreso TV.
According to him, Russian forces might try to use this area as a "gray zone," given reports that Russia has amassed over 60,000 troops nearby. So there could be engagements similar to those near Pokrovsk ‚Äî advances of maybe 500 meters a day at most. At that pace, it would take them six months to a year to reach Sumy. Therefore, there's no reason to panic about a rapid breakthrough in the region.
"Still, Russian artillery can strike up to 20 kilometers deep, as seen in Bilopillia, and FPV drones are active. For instance, on May 17, a minivan was hit by Russian forces just 11 km from the front line on the Sumy‚ÄìBilopillia‚ÄìPutyvl‚ÄìHlukhiv‚ÄìShostka highway. The railway is nearby too. When a train runs from Sumy to Konotop, it speeds up to pass through this high-risk zone near the border. It‚Äôs possible the Russians aim to cut this road, which connects Sumy with communities north of the Siverskyi Donets River. In that sense, they could advance here.
But back in 1943, the Red Army advanced elsewhere ‚Äî around the Pysarivka community, aiming to reach the rear of Kharkiv and sever the Sumy‚ÄìKharkiv highway and rail links. That area lies further south than where the current intense fighting is happening," Bobyrenko concluded.

title: Russian Defeat LOOMS in Ukraine... Putin CAN‚ÄôT ESCAPE This TIME!
description:
On May 19, Foreign Policy detailed why experts now believe Russia is on the brink of defeat in Ukraine. Since the February 2022 invasion, Russia has lost nearly 976,000 troops to death, injury, or capture and over 10,800 tanks. Territorial gains have declined steadily, with only 55‚Äì78 square miles claimed in March 2025.

Compounding these losses is a stagnating Russian economy, with inflation nearing 10% and labor shortages projected to reach 2.4 million workers by 2030. Politically, Putin faces growing pressure as ceasefire negotiations stall and public dissatisfaction rises. As Ukraine begins counter-offensives, experts suggest Russia‚Äôs campaign is not just faltering ‚Äî it may be nearing collapse.

title: Russian strategic aviation aircraft suffer more losses as result of Ukrainian long-range UAV strikes
description:
#Kanal13‚Äã #likekanal13‚Äã #subscribekanal13 #warinukraine
https://www.youtube.com/user/kanal13az?sub_confirmation=1 - SUBSCRIBE TO US!
Russia is moving its strategic aviation aircraft away from Ukraine because it cannot repair them after long-range UAV strikes . This was reported on air by Anatoly Khrapchinsky, deputy general director of the company producing electronic warfare equipment and aviation expert, on Radio NV .

"The enemy doesn't have such problems with tactical aviation. Therefore, he can neglect safety rules a little. Increasing the capacity to produce long-range drones will allow us to turn the 300-kilometer zone around the borders of Ukraine into the so-called Chernobaivka. And it is important to do this so that the enemy simply cannot be at these airfields. When they just start to deploy, the strikes begin," Khrapchinsky said.

He added that this would significantly increase the logistical leverage for the Russians and deprive them of operational speed in some areas of the front.

In addition, the expert explained why the Russians began to draw silhouettes of airplanes on their airfields.

"The Russians understand the threats and are trying to increase the number by drawing. It is difficult to say what they are counting on. After all, what we use as attack UAVs allows us to distinguish whether it is a drawing or a real aircraft. As I understand it, this is so that the technical personnel at the airfield have something to do," Khrapchinsky added.

Recall, , on the night of January 20, 2025, long-range kamikaze drones from Ukraine‚Äôs Defense Forces struck the Kazan Aircraft Production Association , which manufactures Tu-22M3 and Tu-160 strategic bombers.

To begin with, russia is currently incapable of manufacturing entirely new Tu-160 and Tu-22M3 bombers from scratch. To assemble what are officially labeled as "new" aircraft of these types, the russians are forced to use Soviet-era airframes that have been sitting in KAPO workshops for several decades. In russian propaganda terminology, this process is now referred to as "reproduction".

Regarding the Tu-160, open sources indicate that, between 2022 and 2023, as part of the "reproduction" program, russia assembled three bombers of this type from Soviet airframes, designating them as Tu-160M. Additionally, before February 2022, another operational aircraft of this type had been undergoing modernization at KAPO under the same Tu-160M designation. The paradox is that the russian Ministry of Defense now hopes to commission all four Tu-160Ms, each capable of carrying 12 cruise missiles, into the russian Aerospace Forces by at least 2025‚Äîdespite the fact that all four aircraft were initially scheduled for delivery in 2023.

title: The War is Now in Russia: Putin Humiliated as Ukrainian strikes SHUT DOWN airports in Capital Moscow
description:
Is Russia‚Äôs war on Ukraine driving the Kremlin toward economic, military, and social collapse? In this in-depth report, we uncover the May 21 drone attacks that rattled Moscow‚Äôs defenses‚Äîand how a larger, more strategic strike 400 kilometers away devastated a critical semiconductor factory vital to Russia‚Äôs missile and aircraft programs. Beyond the drone raids, we expose the staggering human costs and equipment losses Russia has suffered, the unsustainable militarization of its economy, and the growing gulf between propaganda and reality in Putin‚Äôs regime.

From drastic government spending on defense to the hidden toll on its workforce and infrastructure, this video reveals why experts predict that Russia‚Äôs current path is economically and socially untenable‚Äîand why Vladimir Putin appears more isolated and vulnerable than ever. Join us for a comprehensive look at a conflict reshaping global power dynamics and threatening to dismantle the Kremlin‚Äôs imperial ambitions from within.

title: Russia-Ukraine analyst: Russia 'has started to lose' the war in Ukraine | DW News
description:
On Wednesday, the Kremin announced that Russian President Vladimir Putin had visited Russia's Kursk region on Tuesday. It marked Putin's first visit since Moscow claimed it recaptured Kursk from Ukraininan forces last month. Ukraine's incursion into Kursk in 2024 was the first time a foreign power occupied Russian territory since World War II. 
President Putin has not yet accepted US and European ceasefire proposals, stating that the "root causes of the war" need to be addressed before negotiations can begin. On Wednesday, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov said the motive for a Western-backed truce is for the US and Europe to "calmly arm Ukraine, so that Ukraine can strengthen its defensive positions". 

DW interviews Michael Kimmage, Historian and Associate Professor at the Catholic University of America. He served on the Policy Planning Staff at the U.S. Department of State between 2014 to 2016, where he held the Russia/Ukraine portfolio.

title: Russia-Ukraine War: Putin Visits Kursk For The First Time After Ukrainian Troop Withdrawal |GRAVITAS
description:
Russian President Vladimir Putin visited the Kursk region for the first time since Russian forces pushed out Ukrainian troops last month. He acknowledged the continued challenges in the border area and announced extended financial support for affected residents. Meanwhile, drone footage released by Russia shows a missile strike on a Ukrainian training camp in Sumy, reportedly killing six, though Moscow claims much higher casualties. Amid the escalation, Ukrainian President Zelensky has signaled readiness to meet Putin directly, following calls with U.S. President Trump, though no major progress has been made toward a ceasefire.

title: Ukraine has started evacuating people from Sumy region | DW News
description:
Ukrainian authorities have begun evacuating people from dozens of locations in the Sumy region near the border with Russia. So far, officials have brought over 50,000 people to safety, according to the region's military governor. He says that's about half the number of civilians who need to evacuate. Russia has been heavily attacking Sumy for months. On the other side of the border, Russian President Vladimir Putin has visited Kursk for the first time since Russia said it expelled Ukrainian forces in April. He visited a nuclear plant, which is under construction.

title: Ukraine launches massive attack on Moscow and central regions of Russia with over 150 drones
description:
#Kanal13‚Äã #likekanal13‚Äã #subscribekanal13 #warinukraine
https://www.youtube.com/user/kanal13az?sub_confirmation=1 - SUBSCRIBE TO US!
Attacks on Russia from the Armed Forces continue. Only for today's night in the sky above the Russian Air Force destroyed more than a hundred unmanned aerial vehicles. Details about this have been reported to the Ministry of Defense.

¬´Over the night 127 Ukrainian unmanned aerial vehicles of the aircraft type were intercepted and destroyed by air defense units on duty", ‚Äî says the message of the Telegram channel of the Ministry of Defense.

Ukraine directed its main attack at the Oryol region. According to the Russian Defense Ministry, 53 unmanned aircraft-type aerial vehicles were destroyed in the skies over the Oryol region.

The attack continued all night, and the last 16 drones were shot down in the morning, around eight o'clock Moscow time. There were no reports of casualties or deaths at the time of publication. The region's governor, Andrei Klychkov, said on his Telegram channel that the aftermath of the attack on the ground was being clarified. Drones attacked the Bolkhov factory of semiconductor devices in the Oryol region of the Russian Federation. Photos from the scene of the accident are spreading on social networks: they show a fire and a column of black smoke.

According to the Russian Telegram-channels, the company is connected with the military industry and produces components for radio-electronic equipment, including communication systems, control systems, EW, as well as simulators for tanks and missile complexes.

The plant's products are used by the defense concern "Sozvezdie" and other structures of the Armed Forces of Ukraine.

Six UAVs were intercepted and destroyed by electronic warfare and air defense systems in the Moscow region, three over the territory of the Ryazan region, one each in the skies of the Tula and Kaluga regions, and also over the waters of the Black Sea.

The border regions of Russia were also attacked. The most massive strike of the Ukrainian Armed Forces was in the Bryansk region. The Russian Ministry of Defense reported 51 drones destroyed over the Bryansk region. 36 UAVs were shot down over the Kursk region, and one over the Belgorod region.

The total number of Ukrainian drones destroyed over Russian regions on May 21 increased by 08:00 Moscow time from 127 to 159 units. No drones were spotted in the Samara Region at the time of publication. The threat of attack regime declared at night remains in effect.

title: Russia launching WWII-style breakthrough in Sumy; Ukrainian snipers mass-kill Russian soldiers here
description:
#Kanal13‚Äã #likekanal13‚Äã #subscribekanal13 #warinukraine
https://www.youtube.com/user/kanal13az?sub_confirmation=1 - SUBSCRIBE TO US!
Viktor Bobyrenko, an analyst at the Bureau of Policy and Analysis of Ukraine, believes that the landscape of the Sumy region and the nature of modern warfare will prevent Russian forces from breaking through Ukrainian defenses.
"To avoid sparking panic, let me say right away ‚Äî a large-scale breakthrough in the style of World War II is not possible in Sumy. People here remember 2022, when Russia advanced and was, so to speak, on the outskirts of Sumy by midday. By February 25, the city was sealed off and under siege for a month. Today, there will be no such breakthrough where the enemy reaches Sumy in a day. Warfare is different now.
It‚Äôs simply not feasible because the terrain between the Siverskyi Donets and Psel rivers is not suited for tanks ‚Äî it‚Äôs full of floodplains and a network of ponds. You can‚Äôt maneuver tanks there. However, it‚Äôs a paradise for sabotage and reconnaissance groups and snipers: a landscape with forests and woodlands, the edge of the Central Russian highlands," the analyst explained on Espreso TV.
According to him, Russian forces might try to use this area as a "gray zone," given reports that Russia has amassed over 60,000 troops nearby. So there could be engagements similar to those near Pokrovsk ‚Äî advances of maybe 500 meters a day at most. At that pace, it would take them six months to a year to reach Sumy. Therefore, there's no reason to panic about a rapid breakthrough in the region.
"Still, Russian artillery can strike up to 20 kilometers deep, as seen in Bilopillia, and FPV drones are active. For instance, on May 17, a minivan was hit by Russian forces just 11 km from the front line on the Sumy‚ÄìBilopillia‚ÄìPutyvl‚ÄìHlukhiv‚ÄìShostka highway. The railway is nearby too. When a train runs from Sumy to Konotop, it speeds up to pass through this high-risk zone near the border. It‚Äôs possible the Russians aim to cut this road, which connects Sumy with communities north of the Siverskyi Donets River. In that sense, they could advance here.
But back in 1943, the Red Army advanced elsewhere ‚Äî around the Pysarivka community, aiming to reach the rear of Kharkiv and sever the Sumy‚ÄìKharkiv highway and rail links. That area lies further south than where the current intense fighting is happening," Bobyrenko concluded.

title: No Diplomatic Breakthrough in the Russian Invasion of Ukraine
description:
Go to https://ground.news/kingsandgenerals for a better way to stay informed. Subscribe for 40% off unlimited access to world-wide coverage through my link. 

Kings and Generals animated historical documentary series on modern warfare continues with another video on the Russian Invasion of Ukraine with the updates of April 2025. In this episode, we examine the latest developments in the War in Ukraine as hopes for peace remain elusive as there has been no diplomatic breakthrough despite ongoing discussions and shifting rhetoric. While leaders speak of ceasefires, nothing tangible has materialized on the ground. On the frontlines, our April battlefield overview reveals that Russia continues to press offensives in key areas like Pokrovsk, but with limited gains and high casualties, while Ukraine defends fiercely and launches localized counterattacks. Foreign involvement and support have taken on new dimensions this month. Reports confirm the presence of North Korean troops and even Chinese nationals fighting for Russia, while military aid from Europe expands, contrasting with growing hesitation from the United States. European diplomacy and security guarantees remain uncertain, with shifting tones suggesting that Ukraine may have to rely more heavily on its own forces rather than international peacekeepers. Amidst this, the U.S. peace proposal and reactions have stirred controversy. The Trump administration's suggested deal would recognize some Russian territorial gains, drawing strong opposition from Kyiv and its European allies. As April ends, the conclusion is clear: talks are stalled, the war drags on, and international unity on a resolution remains fragile.

title: LIVE: NATO Chief Gives Statement Amid Ukraine War Negotiations
description:
NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte holds press conference following the Informal Meeting of NATO Foreign Ministers.

READ MORE: https://www.thetimes.com/world/russia-ukraine-war/article/ukraine-russia-peace-talks-latest-news-f0c59f6xg

President Zelensky will make a decision on how the Ukrainian delegation in Istanbul should proceed with peace talks only after meeting President Erdogan of Turkey, a senior official told AFP.

‚ÄúThe president is starting his visit with Erdogan in Ankara, and only then will the president decide on the next steps,‚Äù the official said.

Zelensky‚Äôs plane is thought that have departed from Poland and is expected to land in Ankara at about 9am UK time, Ukrainian media reported. A meeting with Erdogan is believed to be scheduled for 11am UK time.


The peace negotiations in Istanbul between the Ukrainian, Russian, and US delegations are not the only high-level diplomatic talks taking place in Turkey.

Around 250 miles east in the Turkish capital Ankara, President Zelensky will meet President Erdogan this morning.

The US secretary of state, Marco Rubio, is to hold an informal meeting of Nato foreign ministers in the Mediterranean coastal city of Antalya. Rubio will be joined in Antalya by Nato chief Mark Rutte.

On the sidelines of the Nato meeting, the Ukrainian foreign minister, Andrii Sybiha, met on Wednesday with Rubio, who is also having separate talks with new German foreign minister, Johann Wadephul.

title: Russia Ukraine War Ceasefire : Turkey ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç‡§ó‡•á Vladimir Putin-Volodymyr Zelenskyy? | Donald Trump
description:
Russia Ukraine War Ceasefire: Turkey ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç‡§ó‡•á Vladimir Putin- Volodymyr Zelenskyy? | Donald Trump | Russia-Ukraine peace talks in Istanbul | 
Russia Ukraine War Ceasefire : Turkey ƒ∞stanbul ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∏-‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á Donald trump ‡§®‡•á Putin ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ë‡§´‡§∞ ? 

#russiaukrainewar #vladimirputin #volodymyrzelensky 

Peace talks between Russia and Ukraine in Istanbul, scheduled for May 15, 2025, mark the first direct high-level negotiations since March 2022, aimed at ending the ongoing war that began with Russia‚Äôs full-scale invasion in February 2022. Here‚Äôs a concise overview based on current developments 
Previous talks in Istanbul in 2022 produced a draft agreement where Ukraine would adopt neutrality, forgo NATO membership, and limit its military, in exchange for security guarantees from Western nations. These collapsed due to disagreements over security guarantees, the Bucha massacre, and Ukraine‚Äôs reluctance to make constitutional changes.
Russian President Vladimir Putin proposed the talks on May 11, 2025, as a counteroffer to a Western-backed 30-day ceasefire proposal, which he rejected. The Kremlin insists negotiations should build on the 2022 Istanbul draft but reflect current battlefield realities, with Russia controlling about one-fifth of Ukraine, including Crimea and parts of Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporizhzhia, and Kherson.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has insisted on meeting Putin face-to-face, stating he will only negotiate with Putin himself, as ‚Äúonly Putin can make the decision to stop the war.‚Äù Zelenskyy plans to meet Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Ankara first, then travel to Istanbul. The Kremlin has not confirmed Putin‚Äôs attendance, naming a delegation led by Putin‚Äôs aide Vladimir Medinsky, with other lower-level officials, prompting criticism from European leaders and Zelenskyy for Russia‚Äôs lack of seriousness.
U.S. Involvement: U.S. President Donald Trump has prioritized ending the war, urging Zelenskyy to attend the talks. U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and envoys Steve Witkoff and Keith Kellogg are in Istanbul, with Trump indicating he might attend if Putin shows up, though he is not expected to as of now.

Turkey‚Äôs Role: Turkey, maintaining balanced relations with both nations, is hosting the talks, with Erdogan positioning Turkey as a neutral mediator. Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan expressed hope for a ‚Äúnew chapter‚Äù in Europe. The talks coincide with a NATO ministerial meeting in Antalya, adding diplomatic weight.

title: Russian ‚ÄúVictory Parade‚Äù Assault TURNS INTO A BRUTAL DEFEAT! | RFU News
description:
üî¥ Subscribe to our news website today and unlock exclusive strategic and tactical insights: https://www.rfunews.com/pricing

Today, there is interesting news from the Toretsk direction.

Here, the Russian command was forced to achieve a victory to inspire its troops, so they decided to gamble on another suicidal mission. In a bizarre idea, Russians rode across the fields with soviet flags, while Ukrainians used them simply as target practice.

In and around the war-torn Toretsk, the Russian military continues to face stiff resistance and heavy losses. Months of attritional warfare have left much of the city in ruins, turning it into a grey zone, an area where neither side can maintain stable control. Amid these conditions, Russian forces have increasingly shifted their focus to bypassing Toretsk by advancing through surrounding settlements such as Shcherbynivka and its adjoining agglomerations. The Russian objective, to flank the town and force a collapse from the sides, after failing to take it head-on over the past year.

This change in approach follows repeated tactical failures, most notably in Shcherbynivka itself. In earlier offensives, Russian infantry attempted to seize the area, but units from Ukraine‚Äôs Azov Corps decisively cleared them out. For the Russians, gaining control here is not optional. Without it, they cannot hope to isolate Ukrainian forces inside Toretsk or protect themselves from raids and fire missions that continue to harass them from the outskirts.  

On Toretsk‚Äôs northern flank, earlier Russian motorcycle assaults failed miserably, as you might remember from a previous report. Ukrainians responded by recalibrating minefields and integrating more layered defenses, effectively neutralizing the threat. Learning little from these failures, Russian commanders turned their attention to the south, hoping this area, not yet targeted with motorcycles, might offer an opportunity for more success. But this time, they wanted something more than a breakthrough and started a spectacular assault.

What followed was an attempt at psychological warfare, designed to boost the morale of Russian troops before the launch of their summer offensive. Russian soldiers mounted motorcycles, each flying big Russian and Soviet flags as they charged forward. The move was pure symbolism, an apparent effort to film a triumphant advance through a contested sector to boost morale and deliver some ‚Äúgood news‚Äù to the Russian information space. But in practice, these flags served only one real purpose: making the assault troops bigger and more visible targets.

Geolocated footage shows the assault force initially advancing along a single road before splitting into two columns. This maneuver aimed to reduce vulnerability to a single ambush, hoping that at least one group would make it through to their objective. But Ukrainian drone operators were already watching. Alert and experienced, they quickly detected the attackers, and the Ukrainians executed a multi-layered defense with brutal efficiency.

Ukrainian artillery opened fire first, followed by FPV drone strikes that chased the motorcycles across the terrain. Other drones hovered above, dropping grenades on the soldiers with pinpoint accuracy. Riders were knocked off their bikes one by one, their flags falling beside them into the dust. 

Despite the initial barrage, a handful of motorcyclists did manage to escape the first engagement, crawling into the ruins of nearby buildings with the hope of finding cover. Ukrainian forces responded with cluster munitions, saturating the hiding spots with shrapnel. Simultaneously, more drones were deployed, systematically eliminating the surviving Russians. By the end, the only remnants of the attack were burning motorcycles and shredded Russian flags around them.

This failed assault, rather than delivering a morale-boosting spectacle for the Russian soldiers preparing for their renewed offensive effort, became a visual demonstration of Ukrainian dominance on the battlefield. Instead of planting flags on Ukrainian positions, the attackers left behind nothing but charred wreckage and more proof of Russia‚Äôs inability to make meaningful progress and move away from suicidal tactics.

Overall, the operation underscores the desperation within the Russian command. With no territorial success to show, they gambled on an information victory, trying to craft a narrative of momentum with flags and theatrics. But what they received was a disaster captured in real-time: a symbolic assault turned symbolic defeat. With Russian commanders failing to achieve their victory, Russian soldiers and survivors of the previous failed assaults now stand to launch a massive summer offensive with their hopes even further in the gutter.

title: New Ukrainian Incendiary Drones Leave Nothing But Ash! | RFU News
description:
üî¥ Subscribe to our news website today and unlock exclusive strategic and tactical insights: https://www.rfunews.com/pricing

Today, there are a lot of important updates from the Pokrovsk direction.

Here, a Russian mechanized column barely cleared its staging area before Ukrainian incendiary drones swooped immediately to engage them. The strike caught the vehicles in the open, setting equipment and fuel ablaze in mere minutes before the assault had even started.

The goal of the Russian forces in this area is to establish a foothold in Myrnograd to initiate large-scale urban combat in the Pokrovsk-Myrnohrad agglomeration. This is because the southern part of Myrnohrad is distant and detached from the core part of the city, where the bulk of Ukrainian forces are stationed, making it more vulnerable to Russian assaults.

To establish a foothold in Myrnohrad the Russians decided to accumulate forces in Hrodivka from which they would launch a direct mechanized assault towards the town. This is enabled by a 5 kilometer section of a paved asphalt road between Hrodivka and Myrnohrad, allowing the Russian tanks and BMPs to utilize their full speed to reach the city and dismount stormtroopers for urban fighting quickly.

The main tactical disadvantages of the Russian forces in this area is the industrial zone of the nearby coal mine in the southern part of Myrnohrad, which includes high-rise buildings of mineshaft elevators that provide fortified concrete observation points that overlook the Russian route of attack. Additionally, two elevated terrikons in the area allow for additional observation points to overlook all Russian movements around Myrnohrad, together with firing positions. 

Forward Ukrainian positions in the fields before the city include two powerful strongholds built in 2015 and heavily reinforced with concrete bunkers, trenches, and dugouts overlooking the Hrodivka road. Any Russian advance along this route faces deadly ATGM fire from these fortifications. To compound the threat, Ukrainian engineers have scattered anti-tank mines across the road, forcing Russian units to slow and use mine rollers on their lead vehicles, which exposes them further to Ukrainian strikes.

To properly advance and evade Ukrainian fire the Russians would need to maneuver across the fields; however, the Ukrainians anticipated this and built a network of anti-tank ditches and dragon teeth across the fields, effectively turning the Russian road of attack into a killzone. This means that the Russians would be forced to attack Myrnohrad by driving slowly along the paved road and deactivating anti-tank mines, since the surrounding fields are covered with anti-tank ditches and dragon teeth, while the Ukrainians positioned at the terrikon, industrial zone, and trench strongholds have a firing solution on them.

Geolocated combat footage from the area reveals how a Russian mechanized platoon, consisting of a tank and two BMPs, was immediately detected by the Ukrainian forces stationed at observation points as soon as they left Hrodivka and exposed themselves on the road. The lead tank was equipped with a mine roller, with the rest of the convoy moving slowly, meaning that Ukrainians detected them within minutes. As the Russians just started their assault and were not yet within range of Ukrainian soldiers at trenches and terrikon that are armed with ATGM, the Ukrainian FPV drone operators immediately reacted and struck the Russian vehicles engines, effectively immobilizing them. 

This led to a panic among Russian soldiers in the convoy as they thought that they would advance faster if they moved on foot rather than vehicles, only to expose themselves to Ukrainian FPV drones right after leaving their tanks and BMPs, leading to quick eliminations, while others fled to the rear. This left the Russian vehicles abandoned and damaged, but at risk of possible recovery by the nearby Russian forces, so the Ukrainian drone operators targeted open hatches left by the Russian vehicle crews with incendiary drone-dropped grenades that finished them off and blew them up.

Overall, the Russians launched a poorly calculated assault that almost completely ignored the strong networks of fortifications made by the Ukrainians, which forced the Russians in a narrow kill zone where the Ukrainians destroyed an entire mechanized platoon in minutes. This assault is direct result of the intensification of Russian assaults across the Pokrovsk direction, and it is the first Russian mechanized assault here after months of stalemate near Myrnohrad, meaning that attacks here will continue shortly.

title: Ukraine‚Äôs efforts to develop high-tech weapons | DW News
description:
Ukraine‚Äôs President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says he'll travel to Turkey on Thursday to take part in peace talks proposed by Russia and he's called on Russian President Vladimir Putin to meet him in person. 
After more than three years of war, Russia is continuing to take Ukrainian land in grinding battles along the frontline. Overall it's taken about 20 percent of Ukrainian territory. Last year Ukrainian troops took control of part of Russia's Kursk region, but have only held onto a sliver of that territory. 
There are no independently verified casualties figures, but Russia is estimated to have lost somewhere between 200,000 and 250,000 troops. In February, President Zelenskyy said Ukraine had lost 46,000 troops. In addition, some 13,000 Ukrainian civilians have been killed in Russia's full-scale invasion. 
Since Ukraine is outmanned and outgunned by Russia's much larger army, it has concentrated on developing high-tech weapons. DW correspondent, Max Zander has taken a closer look at Ukraine‚Äôs new long-range military drone.

title: Ukrainian drones launch large-scale hunt for Russians attacking on motorcycles, casualties mount
description:
#Kanal13‚Äã #likekanal13‚Äã #subscribekanal13 #warinukraine
https://www.youtube.com/user/kanal13az?sub_confirmation=1 - SUBSCRIBE TO US!
With its armored vehicles running low and Ukrainian drones dominating the skies, the Russian army is being forced to resort to using motorcycles in assault operations. It's a desperate move that could turn into a sensible strategy, Business Insider reports .

The author of the publication admits that motorcycles were used in all the great wars of the machine era, but as a means of transportation in the rear and in the frontline zone. The Russians are probably the first to replace tanks and infantry fighting vehicles with motorcycles in combat.

"Russia's increased use of motorcycles is an adaptation in response to widespread Ukrainian drone strikes on Russian armor and the disproportionate armor losses that Russian forces suffered in late 2023 and 2024," according to a new report from the U.S.-based Institute for the Study of War.

It should be acknowledged that the motorcycle has its obvious strengths - it is a fairly fast and maneuverable vehicle that can overcome a dangerous zone in a short time, avoiding drone strikes. And that is why the Russians seem to be betting on motorcycle assault squads now. At the same time, the use of motorcycles occurs to a certain extent consciously.

"Russian motorcyclists are now attacking in columns of eight motorcycles with the support of electronic warfare (EW) systems. Russian servicemen are carrying EW systems in the front, center and at the end of the columns to protect the motorcycles from attacks by Ukrainian drones," said a Ukrainian soldier who is fighting in the Pokrovsk direction.

Russia uses motorcyclists in two scenarios - either as a "hit and run" method or as a way to quickly break through a fortified defense.

The Institute for the Study of War notes that the use of motorcycles was not an idea of the Russian high command, but a desperate improvisation on the front lines in the face of high losses from Ukrainian drones. The use of drones in the Russian army began in the same way.

The Russian Defense Ministry is currently trying to formally organize frontline operations using motorcycles. In particular, it is proposed to create motorcycle training centers, as well as integrate motorcycle units into regular military formations. This means that the motorcycle assault concept can be extended to all Russian brigades in Ukraine and, possibly, become part of Russian tactics in future wars.

However, the centralized motorization of the Russian army also carries certain risks, analysts say. In particular, it may reduce the ability of the Russian army to adapt to the new realities of the front, analysts note.

Motorcycles have begun to be used for this, and in large numbers. Dozens of motorcyclists can be involved in one attack . In most cases, such attacks end in nothing but huge losses.

title: Zelensky offers to meet Putin after Trump demands Ukraine hold direct talks with Russia | BBC News
description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has said he is ready to meet Russian President Vladimir Putin "personally" in Istanbul on Thursday for talks over ending the war.
 
His post came after Donald Trump demanded Ukraine agree to Putin's offer of direct talks between the two countries in Turkey.
 
Zelensky had earlier said his country was open to talks with Russia but only after a ceasefire was in place.

On Saturday, European leaders urged Russia to agree to an unconditional 30-day ceasefire with Ukraine starting on Monday at a meeting in Kyiv. Putin's offer of direct talks followed that intervention.

title: CANADIAN Soldiers Spill Hard Truth about Russia Ukraine War
description:
CANADIAN Soldiers Spill Hard Truth about Russia Ukraine War

Find out more about the International Defense Legions of Ukraine at the link: https://ildu.mil.gov.ua/

Canadian volunteers fighting alongside Ukraine‚Äôs 3rd Assault Brigade held the line in Avdiivka against overwhelming Russian odds. Outnumbered five to one, they faced constant artillery, drone strikes, ambushes, and freezing nights. From chaotic M113 rides and jammed PKMs to deadly close-quarters combat and last-minute evacuations, this is an unfiltered look at what modern war really feels like.
Their efforts helped Ukrainian forces withdraw from encirclement ‚Äî and forced Russia to throw everything it had into the fight, including outdated BTRs pulled from storage.
